• Trust
• Teamwork
• Togetherness
• Support
• Kindness

April is School Library Month, with National Library Week set for April 19-25. This month represents a time for us to celebrate libraries and the incredible staff who devote their days to transforming learning. Library staff does so even during times of crisis.

Though the current situation has forced libraries to close physical locations temporarily, they remain steadfast providers of continuity of learning with online resources and programming.

I have been impressed to see technology leveraged connecting library staff with students and families via virtual activities. Our school librarians, Pam Verfaillie, Michelle Petersen, and Lorraine Critchlow, have worked tirelessly to ensure educators can effectively utilize online strategies to enhance learning.

Although everyone may be unable to celebrate libraries and librarians this month in face-to-face events, we want to encourage you to take advantage of opportunities to continue education and take a moment to honor these champions.

Sincerely,
Shawn Arnold
Superintendent

The Ravens, our Valdez Homeschool Program's first ever robotics team, were named the champions of the virtual competition held on Saturday, December 7, at Hermon Hutchens Elementary School. They competed against teams from nine other Alaskan communities: Atqasuk, Utqiagvik (Barrow), Cordova, Kaktovik, Kotlik, Petersburg, Point Hope, Wainwright and Valdez. The Ravens, a small two-member, brother team of Wesson and Gunner Lotz, won the overall award for the competition with increasing better round scores of 170, then 205, and a final score of 280! They are invited to attend the Alaska Invitational Robot Rendezvous on Saturday, January 18, in Anchorage at Diamond High School. Congratulations on all of your hard work Ravens, and best of luck in Anchorage!

Special thanks to Mrs. Shidner for starting, developing, and continuing to run the LEGO Robotics program in Valdez, Mrs. Reese and her Tech Team for providing the technical services and support, and all of the involved parents and families. Valdez City Schools is a fun and fantastic place to learn and play.

post_text: Students throughout Valdez City Schools are engaging in cooperative learning structures to enhance their learning and increase the depth of their thinking. By the end of this school year, all teachers will have received Kagan training and begin implementing that training into the classroom. What is Kagan? Kagan is a research-based method to increase student engagement, teach social skills, and hold students accountable for their learning. According to research, classrooms that use Kagan structures increase their standardized achievement scores and decrease behavior referrals. Studies also find that students prefer cooperative learning structures over traditional methods of teaching because the learning is fun, engaging, and students are allowed to interact with their peers (in appropriate ways). For more information about Kagan Cooperative Structures, check out the following video.
